but cobuilders will not prevent a new rb rebalancing for first time rb4 = self._make_coop_builder(4, cb, rebalance=False, min_part_hours=min_part_hours) builders.append(rb4) builder_files = [] for i, builder in enumerate(builders): fname = os.path.join(self.tmpdir, 'builder_%s.builder' % i) builder.save(fname) builder_files.append(fname) cb = CompositeRingBuilder() builder_files, builders = cb.load_components(builder_files) cb.rebalance() self.assertEqual(256, len(self.get_moved_parts(builders[3], rb4))) def test_rebalance_respects_cobuilder_part_moves(self): self._check_rebalance_respects_cobuilder_part_moves(1) self._check_rebalance_respects_cobuilder_part_moves(0) @mock.patch('swift.common.ring.builder.time') def _check_rebalance_cobuilder_states( self, min_part_hours, mock_time): @contextmanager def mock_rebalance(): # wrap rebalance() in order to capture builder states before and # after each component rebalance orig_rebalance = RingBuilder.rebalance # a dict mapping builder -> (list of captured builder states) captured_builder_states = defaultdict(list) def update_states(): for b in cb._builders: rb = CooperativeRingBuilder(8, 3, min_part_hours, None) rb.copy_from(copy.deepcopy(b.to_dict())) rb._part_moved_bitmap = bytearray(b._part_moved_bitmap) captured_builder_states[b].append(rb) def wrap_rebalance(builder_instance): update_states() results = orig_rebalance(builder_instance) update_states() return results with mock.patch('swift.common.ring.RingBuilder.rebalance', wrap_rebalance): yield captured_builder_states mock_time.return_value = now = int(time.time()) builder_files = [] cb = CompositeRingBuilder() for i in (1, 2, 3): b = self._make_coop_builder(i, cb, min_part_hours=min_part_hours) fname = os.path.join(self.tmpdir, 'builder_%s.builder' % i) b.save(fname) builder_files.append(fname) builder_files, builders = cb.load_components(builder_files) # all cobuilders can perform initial rebalance cb.rebalance() # jump forwards min_part_hours now += min_part_hours * 3600 mock_time.return_value = now for builder in builders: self.add_dev(builder) with mock.patch('swift.common.ring.composite_builder.shuffle', lambda x: x): with mock_rebalance() as captured_states: cb.rebalance() # sanity - state captured before and after each component rebalance self.assertEqual(len(builders), len(captured_states)) for states in captured_states.values(): self.assertEqual(2 * len(builders), len(states)) # for each component we have a list of it's builder states rb1s = captured_states[builders[0]] rb2s = captured_states[builders[1]] rb3s = captured_states[builders[2]] # rebalancing will update epoch for all builders' last_part_moves self.assertEqual(now, rb1s[0]._last_part_moves_epoch) self.assertEqual(now, rb2s[0]._last_part_moves_epoch) self.assertEqual(now, rb3s[0]._last_part_moves_epoch) # so, in state before any component rebalance, all can now move parts # _can_part_move so that it doesn't refer to cobuilders state. self.assertEqual(256, self.num_parts_can_move(rb1s[0])) self.assertEqual(256, self.num_parts_can_move(rb2s[0])) self.assertEqual(256, self.num_parts_can_move(rb3s[0])) # after first component has been rebalanced it has moved parts self.assertEqual(64, self.num_parts_can_move(rb1s[1])) self.assertEqual(256, self.num_parts_can_move(rb2s[2])) self.assertEqual(256, self.num_parts_can_move(rb3s[2])) rb1_parts_moved = self.get_moved_parts(rb1s[1], rb1s[0]) self.assertEqual(192, len(rb1_parts_moved)) self.assertEqual(self._partition_counts(rb1s[1]), {0: 192, 1: 192, 2: 192, 3: 192}) rb2_parts_moved = self.get_moved_parts(rb2s[3], rb2s[2]) self.assertEqual(64, len(rb2_parts_moved)) counts = self._partition_counts(rb2s[3]) self.assertEqual(192, self.num_parts_can_move(rb2s[3])) self.assertEqual(64, self.num_parts_can_move(rb1s[3])) self.assertEqual(0, len(self.get_moved_parts(rb3s[5], rb3s[0]))) def test_rebalance_cobuilder_states(self): self._check_rebalance_cobuilder_states(1) self._check_rebalance_cobuilder_states(0) def _check_rebalance_cobuilders_calls(self, min_part_hours): rb1 = self._make_coop_builder(1, cb, min_part_hours=min_part_hours) rb2 = self._make_coop_builder(2, cb, min_part_hours=min_part_hours) # composite rebalance updates last_part_moves before any component # rebalance - after that expect no more updates with mock_update_last_part_moves() as update_calls: cb.update_last_part_moves() self.assertEqual(sorted([rb1, rb2]), sorted(update_calls)) self.assertFalse(update_calls) self.assertFalse(update_calls) def test_rebalance_cobuilders_calls(self): self._check_rebalance_cobuilders_calls(1) self._check_rebalance_cobuilders_calls(0)

Zuul: add run attribute

A proposed change[1] to Zuul removes the implied run attribute.
Add an explicit run attribute here to prepare for that.

commit_message:
Add ansible-role-k8s-cookiecutter under tripleo

TripleO is going to host the ansible-role-k8s-* repos under its umbrela
during the kickstart phase. Hopefully, these projects will grow outside
the tripleo umbrella and become their own team eventually.

The ansible-role-k8s-* repos will contain ansible roles to deploy
openstack services on kubernetes. The cookiecutter template is the first
repo that is being imported under the openstack/tripleo group.

Depends-On: Ie47461c5dab7062ea65a93a49b5c0d651f19a607
Change-Id: Ie3d6d2a108af7e796133a5158678773b34a12ad2

commit_message:
Remove _create_router in scenario.manager

_create_router is used only once in scenario.manager, so this is to:
1. remove _create_router
2. move the logic of creating router to _get_router
3. pass external_gateway_info argument to client.create_router
   instead of using client.update_router
4. use self.__class__.__name__ as prefix of random router name
5. remove self.assertEqual(router['name'], name), and add this
   check in api test test_create_show_list_update_delete_router.

Change-Id: I5aa5a42aaa1ebd654b7e979e3807d3edbf2efa9e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/04/510804/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: name = data_utils.rand_name(self.__class__.__name__ + '-router') name=name, self.assertEqual(router['name'], name)

commit_message:
Remove routers_client from manager._create_subnet

This is to:
1. remove routers_client from manager._create_subnet
   because routers_client is not used for creating subnet.
2. rename _create_subnet to create_subnet for it is used
   by several testcases.

Change-Id: I102c3b01abe0ae752196d27893d43e64acfb57a6

commit_message:
Fix keystonemiddleware.auth_token failure

The senlin script for devstack will setup to use
keystone v2 as default url in keystonemiddleware,
since keystone remove its v2 api, so it will failed
on authentication.

fix-bug: #1727904
Change-Id: I61cf8902eef86efb9cfc82f0061f8b82bfc221f8

commit_message:
Update all SHAs for 15.1.11

This patch updates all the roles to the latest available stable
SHA's, copies the release notes from the updated roles into the
integrated repo, updates all the OpenStack Service SHA's, and
updates the appropriate python requirements pins.

On top of it, ceph-ansible 2.2.11 was pointing to some PPAs that
do not exist anymore. They were changed to include the version
number for nfs-ganesha. This bumps the version to a new tag that
includes the updated PPAs

Co-Authored-By: Sam Yaple <sam@yaple.net>

Depends-On: Id5245ca94ceacb488bf55c4dba0fbc296f0dd304
Change-Id: Ibbba66213782eadae9064fa5d790a181ddbf8d46

commit_message:
Make tox working for zuulv3

Previously taken approach, where python-monascacient, is installed
from the Zuul reference or master made the new ZuulV3 based
tox gates failing.

Change-Id: I864a83862958ec21a681254d7c7a0efb72cf194a

subject: Mention API behavior change when over quota limit
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-27 07:25:08.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/recheck-quota-conf-043a5d6057b33282.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/8649fd10e87b9088a5f00aa9ed436a6081494e1e', 'message': 'Mention API behavior change when over quota limit

In
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/cells-count-resources-to-check-quota-in-api
we introduced a new workflow of Quota checks. It is possible that
concurrent requests can pass API layer checks, but blocked by
conductor layer checks.

This can actually trigger user-noticeable API behavior changes:
As an user, previously, If my request is blocked by quota checks, I will
get HTTP 403 response, and no instance records will be left.

After the above mentioned change, it is possible that when my requests
failed at conductor layer Quota check and I got an instance in ERROR
state. And in an busy cloud, users may got a lot of ERROR instances
according to this and the instance number may beyond the limit.

We should at least mention this behavior change in the release note.

Change-Id: Ib531adc0ae4ddaf92616d3779bd81f519c2f4dec
Closes-Bug: #1718567
'}]
commit_message:
Mention API behavior change when over quota limit

In
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/cells-count-resources-to-check-quota-in-api
we introduced a new workflow of Quota checks. It is possible that
concurrent requests can pass API layer checks, but blocked by
conductor layer checks.

This can actually trigger user-noticeable API behavior changes:
As an user, previously, If my request is blocked by quota checks, I will
get HTTP 403 response, and no instance records will be left.

After the above mentioned change, it is possible that when my requests
failed at conductor layer Quota check and I got an instance in ERROR
state. And in an busy cloud, users may got a lot of ERROR instances
according to this and the instance number may beyond the limit.

We should at least mention this behavior change in the release note.

Change-Id: Ib531adc0ae4ddaf92616d3779bd81f519c2f4dec
Closes-Bug: #1718567
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/69/507769/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Because the quota limit will be rechecked several times, both in API layer and conductor layer, it is possible that requests blocked by over quota would result in instances in the ``ERROR`` state, rather than no instance records before. Operators may want to set the option to False to avoid additional load on the system if allowing quota to be exceeded because of racing requests is considered acceptable.
deleted_lines: Operators may want to set the option to False to avoid additional load on the system if allowing quota to be exceeded because of racing requests is considered acceptable.

commit_message:
doc: Update the URL of noVNC

After being updated to new organization urls [1],
URL of noVNC has been changed from [2] to [3].
This patch set makes sure to use the correct links.

[1] https://github.com/novnc/noVNC/commit/5911cfd58257a3e38818104c941fd977024d3095
[2] https://github.com/kanaka/noVNC
[3] https://github.com/novnc/noVNC

Close-bug: #1727645
Change-Id: Ie8ddb2820eafe226b210e8886da0e89f11274185

subject: Constraint Pandas and Numpy for gnocchi
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-26 11:52:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_gnocchi/commit/c88b8d043c6bff4e2e995564cfb170c8fe3d52cd', 'message': 'pandas and numpy stable versions are provided to be installed.

On Openstack-ansible all the pip packages are mirrored and fetched
on the repo_server.So I realized that pandas version 0.21.0rc1 is installed
but this version is not stable.it is not compatible with numpy 1.12.0 version.
I asked gnocchi channel and they suggested using pandas stable version.
So I provide pandas 0.20.3 and nump 1.12.0 versions to be installed.

Change-Id: If0e2cbebdbdebe7c71851d532b5f8629334b1aaf
Closes-Bug: #1724538
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-10-26 13:05:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_gnocchi/commit/6db9fb39aea2de0368c980e1d45bb5cc97a02def', 'message': "Constraint Pandas and Numpy for gnocchi.

The repo build is building pandas version 0.21.0rc1, incompatible with gnocchi
and numpy.This comes because gnocchi isn't upper constrained, and the version
to be installed is the latest one available (due to a >= requirement).
We should instead constraint both pip packages to make possible to install
gnocchi.

Change-Id: If0e2cbebdbdebe7c71851d532b5f8629334b1aaf
Closes-Bug: #1724538
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-10-26 13:07:07.000000000', 'files': ['defaults/main.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_gnocchi/commit/7fa88e5dec2f2828e3e0f44353932188eb9888ce', 'message': "Constraint Pandas and Numpy for gnocchi

The repo build is building pandas version 0.21.0rc1,
incompatible with gnocchi and numpy. This comes because gnocchi
isn't upper constrained, and the version to be installed is the
latest one available (due to a >= requirement).

We should instead constraint both pip packages to make possible
to install gnocchi.

Change-Id: If0e2cbebdbdebe7c71851d532b5f8629334b1aaf
Closes-Bug: #1724538
"}]
commit_message:
Constraint Pandas and Numpy for gnocchi

The repo build is building pandas version 0.21.0rc1,
incompatible with gnocchi and numpy. This comes because gnocchi
isn't upper constrained, and the version to be installed is the
latest one available (due to a >= requirement).

We should instead constraint both pip packages to make possible
to install gnocchi.

Change-Id: If0e2cbebdbdebe7c71851d532b5f8629334b1aaf
Closes-Bug: #1724538
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_gnocchi refs/changes/76/515376/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Clean up direct publisher

Direct publisher was applied to allow developers to
configure a publisher and provide the correlated dispatcher
interface. Dispatchers are being removed. Besides, the direct
publisher deprected last release and should be removed.

Change-Id: Ie257aa9485e14566b1918621f88b057b4339341f

commit_message:
Set notification_bind on zaqar websocket

Don't let zaqar websocket listen to notifications on all interfaces:
otherwise, it uses the hostname as a subscription target, and it doesn't
work when the host is set as an IPv6 host. Ultimately this should be
fixed in Zaqar, but this will work around it for now.

Change-Id: I78e0671024b93ec64740cd7a8cda227a5145b789
Related-Bug: #1727406
(cherry picked from commit 5fdb4d7913bfc0096c725f6f99fd98e949c75d58)

commit_message:
Fix nova_vnc_proxy, ceilometer_agent_central and aodh_evaluator health check

None of these services connects to RabbitMQ, so we need to verify functionality
of those services different way.

Change-Id: Ic6b51ad6be0d230375bdfb13e04f82629336d070
Closes-Bug: #1724922

commit_message:
Derive Params OvsPmdCoreList compute issue

This change is to compute DPDK derive parameter OvsPmdCoreList
correctly when DPDK NIC is associated to NUMA node 0 or
cores count is mentioned as same for all NUMA nodes.

Change-Id: I5fe6ccbd64a62cf0c6a3f4abf7785837a0d8f8c0
Closes-Bug: #1713733

deleted_lines: While there packages available for Mitaka, they have a `bug <https://bugs.launchpad.net/trove-dashboard/+bug/1580527>`_ which prevents network selection while creating instances. So it is best to install via pip. a compatible version of trove-dashboard. 7.0.0.0b2 is known to work with the Mitaka release of Trove. * After pip installs them locate the trove-dashboard directory and * Reload apache to pick up the changes to Horizon.

commit_message:
Omit outward_rabbitmq from check for upgrade

 Upgrade fails as outward_rabbitmq does not exist
 and cannot therefore be upgraded. Omit it from the
 upgrade check and bootstrap it after rabbitmq upgrade.

 Remove jinja2 from 'Find gospel node' task; removes warnings.

Change-Id: I3766271c62779c8dbd31e7cf2300473815bbbe68

subject: Properly get pip version
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-20 19:16:41.000000000', 'files': ['inc/python'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/065779517f9c99a80fbc39d51784c614e4ee341c', 'message': "Properly get pip version

The old code was strip()ing the version string instead of split()ing the
version string so we always got the first character of the version
string. This worked fine as long as the pip version was single digit but
as soon as it rolls over to '10.stuff' we will compare:

  pip version 1 (instead of 10) > 6

Which fails bceause 1 is less than six. Instaed we really do want to
compare 10 > 6 so use split on '.' instead.

Change-Id: Ic7d0c04d7fa77774ab2d70fb9d11f182becec553
"}]
commit_message:
Properly get pip version

The old code was strip()ing the version string instead of split()ing the
version string so we always got the first character of the version
string. This worked fine as long as the pip version was single digit but
as soon as it rolls over to '10.stuff' we will compare:

  pip version 1 (instead of 10) > 6

Which fails bceause 1 is less than six. Instaed we really do want to
compare 10 > 6 so use split on '.' instead.

Change-Id: Ic7d0c04d7fa77774ab2d70fb9d11f182becec553
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/32/513832/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: print(pip.__version__.split('.')[0])")

commit_message:
Remove usage of 'tripleo' gate queue

The gate is currently killing us with resets (caused by timeouts, being
investigated by the team).

Right now, the common queue doesn't help us, we want to get rid of it
until we stabilize things again.

Change-Id: I5a887010b137baffbe9b78811a30d5379733df34

subject: Drop MANIFEST.in - it's not needed by pbr
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-08-31 01:08:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/storlets/commit/9d87dd3b5b9c36282353ae4dc99b7e7272bf45cf', 'message': "Drop MANIFEST.in - it's not needed by pbr

Storlets already uses PBR:-
setuptools.setup(
    setup_requires=['pbr>=1.9', 'setuptools>=17.1'],
    pbr=True)

This patch removes `MANIFEST.in` file as pbr generates a
sensible manifest from git files and some standard files

commit_message:
Drop MANIFEST.in - it's not needed by pbr

Storlets already uses PBR:-
setuptools.setup(
    setup_requires=['pbr>=1.9', 'setuptools>=17.1'],
    pbr=True)

This patch removes `MANIFEST.in` file as pbr generates a
sensible manifest from git files and some standard files
and it removes the need for an explicit `MANIFEST.in` file.

Change-Id: Id5687622ecdbc4db33f48f1906ae1027deacd2ed
Closes-Bug: #1608980

commit_message:
Add installation guide, contributor guide and configuration guide.

Change-Id: I67232b9a6c50ca7f68c733b2a0796df89d40378d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-dashboard refs/changes/94/514594/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Use Heat Dashboard in DevStack ------------------------------ Set up your ``local.conf`` to enable heat-dashboard:: [[local|localrc]] enable_plugin heat-dashboard https://git.openstack.org/openstack/heat-dashboard Manual Installation ------------------- Clone both Horizon and Heat Dashboard repositories:: git clone https://github.com/openstack/horizon git clone https://github.com/openstack/heat-dashboard Create a virtual environment and install dependent packages:: cd horizon python tools/install_venv.py Set up your ``local_settings.py`` file:: cp openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py.example \ openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py Open newly created ``local_settings.py`` with your text editor, and set some parameter to connect to your OpenStack environment: - Set ``OPENSTACK_HOST`` as hostname or IP address of your OpenStack server. - Verify that the ``OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_URL`` and ``OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DEFAULT_ROLE`` settings are correct for your environment. (They should be correct unless you modified your OpenStack server to change them.) Install Heat Dashboard and all dependent packages into your virtual environment:: tools/with_venv.sh pip install -e ../heat-dashboard/ Enable heat-dashboard plugin in your Horizon environment:: cp ../heat-dashboard/heat_dashboard/enabled/* \ openstack_dashboard/local/enabled Finally you can run Horizon with Heat Dashboard plugin:: python manage.py runserver 0.0.0.0:8080 Now you can connect to your Horizon including Heat Dashboard plugin from your browser with URL http://localhost:8080/.

commit_message:
WIP: Add functional resize tests using shared storage

Still needs work on confirming the resize and checking
allocations after that. This does show the issue though
since the healing task in the compute service actually
fails to overwrite the allocations for the instance for
all providers because it 409s trying to allocate DISK_GB
to the compute node provider which has no DISK_GB inventory.

Many of the tests from the superclass are currently marked
as TODOs in the subclass.

Change-Id: Ia59c82166562a99a584d0267da6b5934c1bef4cd
Related-Bug: #1707256
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/33/490733/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os_traits from nova.tests import uuidsentinel as uuids _compute_driver = 'fake.FakeDriver' self.flags(compute_driver=self._compute_driver) self.placement_api.version = 'latest' def _get_provider_inventories(self, provider_uuid): """Get the inventories for the given resource provider :param provider_uuid: UUID of the resource provider to get inventories :returns: dict, keyed by resource class name, of inventories for the given resource provider """ return self.placement_api.get( '/resource_providers/%s/inventories' % provider_uuid).body['inventories'] def assertFlavorMatchesAllocation(self, flavor, allocation, shared_disk=False): """Asserts the flavor resources match the allocation/usage for a compute node resource provider. :param flavor: The flavor to compare to the allocation. :param allocation: The resource allocation to compare to the flavor. :param shared_disk: If True, DISK_GB allocation should be missing from a compute node provider, else it should match the flavor disk. """ if not shared_disk: self.assertEqual(flavor['disk'], allocation['DISK_GB']) else: self.assertNotIn('DISK_GB', allocation) def _boot_and_check_allocations(self, flavor, source_hostname, shared_storage_provider_uuid=None): """Create a server and check allocations on the resource providers :param flavor: The flavor with which to create the server. :param source_hostname: The host on which to create the server. :param shared_storage_provider_uuid: The UUID of a shared storage resource provider if using one for DISK_GB, else None. :returns: The server representation. We need to use a fake driver with no local disk # so that the scheduler (placement) will be forced # to pick the shared storage provider for disk resources. _compute_driver = 'fake.NoDiskFakeDriver' def _setup_shared_storage_provider(self): """Creates a shared storage DISK_GB resource provider in the Placement service that is in a resource provider aggregate relationship with the two compute node resource providers. :returns: A tuple consisting of the shared storage provider UUID, the compute node 1 provider UUID, and the compute node 2 provider UUID """ # subject: DNM: Test multi-cell (2)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-26 15:15:49.000000000', 'files': ['lib/nova'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/129eab29a2930ea11729b8c0ea41927780229887', 'message': "DNM: Test multi-cell (2)

The dvr-ha multinode job that runs in the devstack
experimental queue is a 3-node job, so it would be
cool to test out real multiple cells. We know things
like migration operations between cells aren't supported

what blows up.

Change-Id: Ia39a4d4e4f0e01852ffc4218d74c4dc96607391f

commit_message:
DNM: Test multi-cell (2)

The dvr-ha multinode job that runs in the devstack
experimental queue is a 3-node job, so it would be
cool to test out real multiple cells. We know things
like migration operations between cells aren't supported
and that might cause some tests to fail, but let's see
what blows up.

Change-Id: Ia39a4d4e4f0e01852ffc4218d74c4dc96607391f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/79/487479/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
DNM: test new style volume attach with live migration

This pulls together the two changes to enable new-style
volume attachments using cinder 3.27 and the change
which triggers new live migration logic when the
volumes are attached in that new style.

Eventually once this is passing the live migration job we'll
line these up in the same series such that the live migration
change comes before the API changes for using new style
volume attachments.

Depends-On: Ifc01dbf98545104c998ab96f65ff8623a6db0f28
Depends-On: I0bfb11296430dfffe9b091ae7c3a793617bd9d0d

Also depends on a Tempest change to unskip the
test_volume_backed_live_migration test.

Depends-On: If90f6d693a09c442c9d354d62219edc962da547f

This change depends on an update to test_iscsi_volume in Tempest
for additional volume attachment validation.

Depends-On: I72ccf82debe36607b58fa75e52af535494999959

Change-Id: I1e5272cff8234cf6085e0c937f24633fe9c60b36

subject: Avoid unnecessary lazy-loads in mutated_migration_context
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-06 21:30:59.000000000', 'files': ['nova/objects/instance.py', 'nova/tests/unit/objects/test_instance.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c3d466dd4d9739844404fdd9c4170c4a8284a4aa', 'message': "Avoid unnecessary lazy-loads in mutated_migration_context

If the instance isn't being migrated and has the
migration_context attribute set to None, like during a rebuild
operation, we should detect that and exit early rather
than lazy-load several fields (numa_topology, pci_requests,
and pci_devices - all separately) and then just not use/need
them.

Change-Id: I071ab575bfd80db029d542cebfdb3d4e34227881
Closes-Bug: #1696221
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid unnecessary lazy-loads in mutated_migration_context

If the instance isn't being migrated and has the
migration_context attribute set to None, like during a rebuild
operation, we should detect that and exit early rather
than lazy-load several fields (numa_topology, pci_requests,
and pci_devices - all separately) and then just not use/need
them.

Change-Id: I071ab575bfd80db029d542cebfdb3d4e34227881
Closes-Bug: #1696221
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/86/471486/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch('nova.objects.Instance.obj_load_attr', new_callable=mock.NonCallableMock) # asserts not called def test_mutated_migration_context_early_exit(self, obj_load_attr): """Tests that we exit early from mutated_migration_context if the migration_context attribute is set to None meaning this instance is not being migrated. """ inst = instance.Instance(context=self.context, migration_context=None) for attr in instance._MIGRATION_CONTEXT_ATTRS: self.assertNotIn(attr, inst) with inst.mutated_migration_context(): for attr in instance._MIGRATION_CONTEXT_ATTRS: self.assertNotIn(attr, inst)

commit_message:
Optimize zuul v3 jobs

- move check container failure from post.yml to run.yml
- add binary related jobs
- use static kolla-ansible src dir, which is helpful for kolla project
  to use.
- generate correct /etc/hosts by using private ip address and hostname
- fix the wrong api interface in global.yml file

Change-Id: Idfdee6dfe18f0fa2d4f984df59b57553122ce298
(cherry picked from commit bc3b7a7477975467e80d0d0b17a3f5693300d904)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/17/514517/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: check_failure() { # All docker container's status are created, restarting, running, removing, # paused, exited and dead. Containers without running status are treated as # failure. removing is added in docker 1.13, just ignore it now. failed_containers=$(sudo docker ps -a --format "{{.Names}}" \ --filter status=created \ --filter status=restarting \ --filter status=paused \ --filter status=exited \ --filter status=dead) if [[ -n "$failed_containers" ]]; then exit 1; fi } check_failure

Updated templates for heat-dashboard

heat-dashboard needs openstack/horizon as required-projects to run the
relevant jobs.  Therefore updated templates of heat-dashboard in
zuul.d/projects.yaml

commit_message:
Update neutron-failure-rate grafana dashboard

Re-arrange to have gate jobs at top, check jobs after, followed
by periodic jobs, etc.

Also added some missing jobs from last update:
 - legacy-tempest-dsvm-py35 (gate and check)
 - ironic-tempest-dsvm-ipa-wholedisk-bios-agent_ipmitool-tinyipa
 - build-openstack-sphinx-docs

Added note at top to denote 'No datapoints' meant there had been
no job failures reported yet for a section.

Change-Id: Ida0ce854a32a01eeb8e75978e267b321c5a5d510

subject: Use generic user for both zuul v2 and v3
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-18 02:33:58.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/gate/post_test_hook.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/searchlight/commit/72d73251171e3faec225bc83d0cadcdcf7bd8f58', 'message': "Use generic user for both zuul v2 and v3

Zuul v2 uses 'jenkins' as user, but Zuul v3 uses 'zuul'.
Using $USER solves it for both cases.

Change-Id: I7483b38c4af5b02813bbc5ff950b703cfae5f9df
"}]
commit_message:
Use generic user for both zuul v2 and v3

Zuul v2 uses 'jenkins' as user, but Zuul v3 uses 'zuul'.
Using $USER solves it for both cases.

Change-Id: I7483b38c4af5b02813bbc5ff950b703cfae5f9df
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/18/512918/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo chown $USER:$USER $BASE/logs/testrepository.subunit.gz $BASE/logs/testr_results.html.gz

plugin. Since we would like to add this plugin into OpenStackClient
doc, we need rsdclient to be part of this list so that other projects
could add it into the requirements.txt.

Questions for new requirement:

1. Is the library actively maintained?

Yes, python-rsdclient released the initial version in this month and
will continue to support further RSD version in the future.
https://github.com/openstack/python-rsdclient

2. Is the library good code?

This library followed the OpenStack convention to add all necessary
unit test cases, and the OpenStackClient plugin provided by this
project has passed related OpenStackClient tests.

3. Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes, it is compatible with python 3, and passed all python 3 test
cases.

4. Is the library license compatible?

Yes, it released under Apache 2.0 license.

5. Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
latest / Fedora latest)?

Current it has not been packaged in any distros, because it just
released the initial version 0.1.0.

6.Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries
in global-requirements.txt?

No, this library provides the specific RSD OSC plugin, which it
reason why this library is created.

7. Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes, when add the RSD plugin into OpenStackClient plugin list, it
requires it has been add global requirements at first, then OSC will
install it to automatically generate usage document.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/511683/

8. If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process
does it use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

This project is not released by the OpenStack release project, because
it is not official OpenStack project, but only provides specific RSD
plugin to allow user to invoke RSD API through OpenStackClient.

9. Do I need to update anything else?

No, the initial version also has been added into upper-constraints.txt.

Change-Id: I156cdfbd0afaf9f7e5f41749545e2b8bff663b96

commit_message:
Add RSD client into requirements

RSD client has released the first version of its OpenStackClient
plugin. Since we would like to add this plugin into OpenStackClient
doc, we need rsdclient to be part of this list so that other projects
could add it into the requirements.txt.

Questions for new requirement:

1. Is the library actively maintained?

Yes, python-rsdclient released the initial version in this month and
will continue to support further RSD version in the future.
https://github.com/openstack/python-rsdclient

2. Is the library good code?

This library followed the OpenStack convention to add all necessary
unit test cases, and the OpenStackClient plugin provided by this
project has passed related OpenStackClient tests.

3. Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes, it is compatible with python 3, and passed all python 3 test
cases.

4. Is the library license compatible?

Yes, it released under Apache 2.0 license.

5. Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
latest / Fedora latest)?

Current it has not been packaged in any distros, because it just
released the initial version 0.1.0.

6.Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries
in global-requirements.txt?

No, this library provides the specific RSD OSC plugin, which it
reason why this library is created.

7. Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes, when add the RSD plugin into OpenStackClient plugin list, it
requires it has been add global requirements at first, then OSC will
install it to automatically generate usage document.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/511683/

8. If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process
does it use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

This project is not released by the OpenStack release project, because
it is not official OpenStack project, but only provides specific RSD
plugin to allow user to invoke RSD API through OpenStackClient.

9. Do I need to update anything else?

No, the initial version also has been added into upper-constraints.txt.

Change-Id: I156cdfbd0afaf9f7e5f41749545e2b8bff663b96

commit_message:
Haproxy VIP address override

The haproxy playbook now has a variable for vip endpoint addresses which
can be used to override them based on the needs of the deployment. This
is extremely useful in cases where the `*_lb_vip_address`(s) are nat'd.
The new variables are  `haproxy_external_lb_vip_address` which has a
default of `external_lb_vip_address` and `haproxy_internal_lb_vip_address`
with a default of `internal_lb_vip_address`.

Change-Id: I13154c5de492cf51829bfa3573ec3e17bd920623
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/73/475573/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: external_lb_vip_address: "{{ haproxy_external_lb_vip_address | default(external_lb_vip_address) }}" internal_lb_vip_address: "{{ haproxy_internal_lb_vip_address | default(internal_lb_vip_address) }}"

commit_message:
use external net api def from lib

The external network extension's API definition was rehomed into
neutron-lib with I9933b91d1e82db3891b3b72f06e94316e56a4f15. This patch
consumes it, switching over to neutron-lib's modules in prep for
I696b52265b9528082cd2524f05febe2338376488

Change-Id: Id1dfe8cf0ec50f1206dd997c9303756683ab5e00

commit_message:
Use Sphinx 1.5 warning-is-error

With pbr 2.0 and Sphinx 1.5, the setting for treat sphinx warnings as
errors is setting warning-is-error in build_sphinx section.

Change-Id: I94fb715f0687964257d86f2f590ea0b4c4f1fd50
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/anchor refs/changes/42/512542/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make gate-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration-nv experimental

This job has been 100% fail since around August 18 so move it
to the experimental queue so we don't waste time and resources
on a broken job.

Change-Id: Ia59766d71d9437861353e586ac1787655e82e4d3
Related-Bug: #1720191
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/44/508244/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(mriedem): gate-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration-nv # runs in the experimental queue until bug 1720191 is fixed. - gate-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration-nv

In order to make it simpler to use the default
configuration files when deploying services
from source, the files are added to pbr's
data_files section so that the files are
included in the built wheels and therefore
deployed with the code. Packaging and deployment
tools can then more easily use the default files
if they wish to.

This pattern is already established with similar
files for neutron, designate and glance as has
been mentioned in the related bug report.

commit_message:
Add default configuration files to data_files

In order to make it simpler to use the default
configuration files when deploying services
from source, the files are added to pbr's
data_files section so that the files are
included in the built wheels and therefore
deployed with the code. Packaging and deployment
tools can then more easily use the default files
if they wish to.

This pattern is already established with similar
files for neutron, designate and glance as has
been mentioned in the related bug report.

Change-Id: Iaa47bcb1a9eb34caddc80a813a703eea591142e7
Closes-Bug: #1718356

commit_message:
conf: Move additional nova-net opts to 'network'

Change I40b2372 moved some nova-network opts from 'floating_ips' to
'network'. It turns out there are more nova-network opts in other files.
Move some of these for the same reasons given in that change.

Note that there are still other nova-network opts in other files.
However, these are all in non-DEFAULT groups and should stay where
they are for now.

Change-Id: Id734bc751566a80a296af204dbbfc09fca5e34b8

commit_message:
WIP reorder destination host setup

- experimental change to test if reordering
  self.network_api.setup_networks_on_host
  before calling self.driver.pre_live_migration
  will break existing workflow.

- This change should allow regeneration of the
  instance defintion to account for changes in
  port bindings between source and target hosts.

- This change should not be merged as written as
  it will break connectivity for the instance
  when the portbinding is updated. The correct
  change is to create a new port binding for the
  destination but not activate it until we plug
  the interface on the destination host.

- multiple bindings is requied to enable the late
  activation and will be introduced by
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/414251/

Change-Id: I57be2c9534fd865fe1c9fa2c254e0a62a8158405

commit_message:
Bypass web server during service setup

When connecting directly to a keystone host during service setup, use
the UWSGI ports instead of going through the web server to avoid any
potential errors with differing URI protocols or SSL certs not including
the hostnames of individual hosts.

Change-Id: Ie5b33f9d0210a23badb63cab72c481b027790be3
Closes-Bug: 1699191
(cherry picked from commit cabd7e9cef8c35df08958677892a82551b210c97)

subject: Fix scheduler_host_manager limitation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-03 10:35:40.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/scheduler/host_manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/46e1190e6b5c2a1910c2375a8be41c28330950ae', 'message': "Fix scheduler_host_manager limitation

We support customization of scheduler's host manager, driver, and
filters, but when we made the scheduler Pool aware we greatly limited
this possibility because now instead of passing BackendState (previously
called HostState) to the filters we are passing PoolState, which cannot
be easily customized.

Prior to this if you wanted to have a custom BackendState class you
would just have to extend HostManager class and define the class
attribute backend_state_cls before using it in config's
scheduler_host_manager.

Now it will not be enough with that because PoolState class is hardcoded
in the BackendState's methods, so you'll have to actually copy all the
code from that class just so you can replace the PoolState class
instantiations.

This patch fixes this by creating an instance attribute on
initialization method, this way extending classes will just have to call
parent's initialization and then replace the value of the pool_state_cls
attribute.

Due to a circular dependency between BackendState and PoolState (which
inherits from BackendState) we cannot just add it as a class attribute,
so we do it as an instance attribute instead.

If we want to add it as a class attribute we would have to add after the
PoolState class definition the following:

 BackendState.pool_state_cls = PoolState

Conceptually that's closer to what we want (a class attribute) but the
implementation is worse because you end up assigning the class attribute
270 lines away from where it should have been defined.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I2c63806c4e9b1305742c7f07f47b95ba243c1666
"}]
commit_message:
Fix scheduler_host_manager limitation

We support customization of scheduler's host manager, driver, and
filters, but when we made the scheduler Pool aware we greatly limited
this possibility because now instead of passing BackendState (previously
called HostState) to the filters we are passing PoolState, which cannot
be easily customized.

Prior to this if you wanted to have a custom BackendState class you
would just have to extend HostManager class and define the class
attribute backend_state_cls before using it in config's
scheduler_host_manager.

Now it will not be enough with that because PoolState class is hardcoded
in the BackendState's methods, so you'll have to actually copy all the
code from that class just so you can replace the PoolState class
instantiations.

This patch fixes this by creating an instance attribute on
initialization method, this way extending classes will just have to call
parent's initialization and then replace the value of the pool_state_cls
attribute.

Due to a circular dependency between BackendState and PoolState (which
inherits from BackendState) we cannot just add it as a class attribute,
so we do it as an instance attribute instead.

If we want to add it as a class attribute we would have to add after the
PoolState class definition the following:

 BackendState.pool_state_cls = PoolState

Conceptually that's closer to what we want (a class attribute) but the
implementation is worse because you end up assigning the class attribute
270 lines away from where it should have been defined.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I2c63806c4e9b1305742c7f07f47b95ba243c1666
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/75/479775/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(geguileo): We have a circular dependency between BackendState # and PoolState and we resolve it with an instance attribute instead # of a class attribute that we would assign after the PoolState # declaration because this way we avoid splitting the code. self.pool_state_cls = PoolState cur_pool = self.pool_state_cls(self.host, self.cluster_name, pool_cap, pool_name) single_pool = self.pool_state_cls(self.host, self.cluster_name, capability, pool_name) single_pool = self.pool_state_cls(self.host, self.cluster_name, capability, pool_name)
deleted_lines: cur_pool = PoolState(self.host, self.cluster_name, pool_cap, pool_name) single_pool = PoolState(self.host, self.cluster_name, capability, pool_name) single_pool = PoolState(self.host, self.cluster_name, capability, pool_name)

commit_message:
use deliverable type service to derive python-server release type

Avoid having to set the release type for things that are python
service but that have npm-based components.

Change-Id: Ia600753b4090939ab07745847d39200bd3fad6c3
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add functions for managing DNS Entries

Add code for managing DNS Entries via hacluster. This is part of the
effort to enable DNS HA in the reactive charms.

Change-Id: I1a6cdeffa3aa8657b957ba68cd09face27f93b27
Partial-Bug: #1727376
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-interface-hacluster refs/changes/96/515396/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def add_dnsha(self, name, ip, fqdn, endpoint_type): """Add a DNS entry to self.resources :param name: string - Name of service :param ip: string - IP address dns entry should resolve to :param fqdn: string - The DNS entry name :param endpoint_type: string - Public, private, internal etc :returns: None """ resource_dict = self.get_local('resources') if resource_dict: resources = relations.hacluster.common.CRM(**resource_dict) else: resources = relations.hacluster.common.CRM() resources.add( relations.hacluster.common.DNSEntry(name, ip, fqdn, endpoint_type)) # DNS Group group = 'grp_{}_hostnames'.format(name) dns_res_group_members = [] if resource_dict: dns_resources = resource_dict.get('resources') if dns_resources: for dns_res in dns_resources: if 'hostname' in dns_res: dns_res_group_members.append(dns_res) resources.group(group, *dns_res_group_members) self.set_local(resources=resources)

commit_message:
Fix AttributeError in BlockDeviceMapping.obj_load_attr

The BDM has no uuid attribute so the debug message in here
would result in an AttributeError. This has been around since
the creation of this object, and the debug log message was
probably copied from the Instance object.

This was only exposed in Pike when this code started
lazy-loading the instance field:

  I1dc54a38f02bb48921bcbc4c2fdcc2c946e783c1

So this change fixes that bug and adds tests for obj_load_attr.

Change-Id: I8b55227b1530a76c2f396c035384abd89237d936
Closes-Bug: #1726871
(cherry picked from commit 1ca191fcc4d809c991c23dedc951bbe7206edf1d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/04/515404/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add configure-swap role

This is a role to configure swap and /opt on an infra host.

Originally we wrote this for devstack-gate with
Icd4e6d8ab84471ad06e69c3e0f9bac92776efc78.  It was ported into the
native devstack job with Iffe54fbccbccd68db08f79a1b51dd7f76dbff408.

This is really generic, and it's quite possible non-devstack jobs
would like to setup swap for jobs too, so o-z-j is a better home for
the role.

Change-Id: I0e9c846ace7fac8a1340746c6818fba6ec963018
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs refs/changes/95/513595/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- # Configure attached ephemeral devices for storage and swap - assert: that: - "ephemeral_device is defined" - name: Set partition names set_fact: swap_partition: "{{ ephemeral_device}}1" opt_partition: "{{ ephemeral_device}}2" - name: Ensure ephemeral device is unmounted become: yes mount: name: "{{ ephemeral_device }}" state: unmounted - name: Get existing partitions become: yes parted: device: "{{ ephemeral_device }}" unit: MiB register: ephemeral_partitions - name: Remove any existing partitions become: yes parted: device: "{{ ephemeral_device }}" number: "{{ item.num }}" state: absent with_items: - "{{ ephemeral_partitions.partitions }}" - name: Create new disk label become: yes parted: label: msdos device: "{{ ephemeral_device }}" - name: Create swap partition become: yes parted: device: "{{ ephemeral_device }}" number: 1 state: present part_start: '0%' part_end: "{{ configure_swap_size }}MiB" - name: Create opt partition become: yes parted: device: "{{ ephemeral_device }}" number: 2 state: present part_start: "{{ configure_swap_size }}MiB" part_end: "100%" - name: Make swap on partition become: yes command: "mkswap {{ swap_partition }}" - name: Write swap to fstab become: yes mount: path: none src: "{{ swap_partition }}" fstype: swap opts: sw passno: 0 dump: 0 state: present # XXX: does "parted" plugin ensure the partition is available # before moving on? No udev settles here ... - name: Add all swap become: yes command: swapon -a - name: Create /opt filesystem become: yes filesystem: fstype: ext4 # The default ratio is 16384 bytes per inode or so. Reduce that to 8192 # bytes per inode so that we get roughly twice the number of inodes as # by default. This should still be well above the block size of 4096. # We do this because we have found in at least a couple locations that # more inodes is useful and is painful to fix after the fact. opts: -i 8192 dev: "{{ opt_partition }}" # Rackspace at least does not have enough room for two devstack # installs on the primary partition. We copy in the existing /opt to # the new partition on the ephemeral device, and then overmount /opt # to there for the test runs. # # NOTE(ianw): the existing "mount" touches fstab. There is currently (Sep2017) # work in [1] to split mount & fstab into separate parts, but for now we bundle # it into an atomic shell command # [1] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/27174 - name: Copy old /opt become: yes shell: | mount {{ opt_partition }} /mnt find /opt/ -mindepth 1 -maxdepth 1 -exec mv {} /mnt/ \; umount /mnt # This overmounts any existing /opt - name: Add opt to fstab and mount become: yes mount: path: /opt src: "{{ opt_partition }}" fstype: ext4 opts: noatime state: mounted

subject: Create dir needed to publish gerrit plugins
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-26 16:31:26.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/legacy/its-storyboard-gerrit-plugin-stable-2.13/post.yaml', 'playbooks/legacy/javamelody-gerrit-plugin-stable-2.13/post.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/commit/9a8783fae389652ac1a0f7d18cb668ae0cb47df6', 'message': 'Create dir needed to publish gerrit plugins

rsync will only create a single directory to copy contents in so we need
to create every dir level above that. In this case are copying to
$workdir/artifacts/plugins/$plugin and were only creating the artifacts
dir and rsync will only attempt to mkdir $plugin so this fails on
missing the plugins dir.

Fix this by also creating the plugins dir.

Change-Id: I93ecb3d39cc751bb7d4a17173fd02e41ea77b620

commit_message:
Create dir needed to publish gerrit plugins

rsync will only create a single directory to copy contents in so we need
to create every dir level above that. In this case are copying to
$workdir/artifacts/plugins/$plugin and were only creating the artifacts
dir and rsync will only attempt to mkdir $plugin so this fails on
missing the plugins dir.

Fix this by also creating the plugins dir.

Change-Id: I93ecb3d39cc751bb7d4a17173fd02e41ea77b620

commit_message:
Make the event streamer transport URL configurable

This adds a way to configure the event streamer transport URL
so it can post to a different queue, e.g. Neutron's

Change-Id: I69d3d6d30e33878052f2c56b8c79a14cc4ec1b24
(cherry picked from commit 060fcc1503c2b0edcb2f093305397fd23dc60b73)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/34/515534/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Transport URL to use for the neutron-lbaas synchronization event stream # when neutron and octavia have separate queues. # For Single Host, specify one full transport URL: # event_stream_transport_url = rabbit://<user>:<pass>@127.0.0.1:5672/<vhost> # For HA, specify queue nodes in cluster, comma delimited: # event_stream_transport_url = rabbit://<user>:<pass>@server01,<user>:<pass>@server02/<vhost> # event_stream_transport_url =

commit_message:
Create openstack-zuul-jobs-linters jobs

This will be a cross repo linter jobs for openstack-zuul-jobs,
project-config and zuul-jobs.

Each repo will be able to run this job, which sets up all our projects
roles in the correct locations.

Depends-On: I59e5d41a9539671ee5aab9b9036379eb9101d021
Change-Id: I16186c929e7d0e6e34b35271559e555255a52b00
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs refs/changes/15/512715/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - job: name: openstack-zuul-jobs-linters parent: tox description: | This job runs against project-config, openstack-zuul-jobs and zuul-jobs so we can properly lint our ansible playbooks / roles run: playbooks/linters/run required-projects: - openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs - openstack-infra/project-config - openstack-infra/zuul-jobs vars: tox_envlist: linters zuul_work_dir: "src/git.openstack.org/openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs"

commit_message:
Convert 'server' commands to use autoprogram

Convert the remaining server commands.

Change-Id: Ief84abb899be9fd60ce4d546abefc226e0ae4f81
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/52/458452/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: instance. The backup command manages the number of archival copies to retain... autoprogram-cliff:: openstack.compute.v2 :command: server backup create
deleted_lines: instance. The backup command manages the number of archival copies to retain.server backup create -------------------- Create a server backup image .. program:: server create .. code:: bash openstack server backup create [--name <image-name>] [--type <backup-type>] [--rotate <count>] [--wait] <server> .. option:: --name <image-name> Name of the backup image (default: server name) .. option:: --type <backup-type> Used to populate the ``backup_type`` property of the backup image (default: empty) .. option:: --rotate <count> Number of backup images to keep (default: 1) .. option:: --wait Wait for operation to complete .. describe:: <server> Server to back up (name or ID)

commit_message:
Make the event streamer transport URL configurable

This adds a way to configure the event streamer transport URL
so it can post to a different queue, e.g. Neutron's

Change-Id: I69d3d6d30e33878052f2c56b8c79a14cc4ec1b24
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/52/514452/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if cfg.CONF.oslo_messaging.event_stream_transport: self.transport = oslo_messaging.get_rpc_transport( cfg.CONF, cfg.CONF.oslo_messaging.event_stream_transport) else: self.transport = oslo_messaging.get_rpc_transport(cfg.CONF)

commit_message:
Switch to keystone v3 API for validate-simple on master

This fixes errors during the pingtest, as the v2 API is not available on
Queens overcloud.

Change-Id: I600ee25a9a29192b6b1755ec7032ed52bd9ae394
Closes-bug: #1727698

commit_message:
Newton-EOL: Remove obsolete jobs and branches

Remove obsolete branches and jobs that are now unused with newton EOL
for most repos.

This removes also some driverfix branch conditions and jobs on repos
where the automatic migration added jobs/conditions wrongly.

Needed-By: I2bba5e38114932f694260f49a3da8a0c544a2822
Change-Id: Idc2319f7425b8d9f7c1ba3ef9c61aa604408476e

commit_message:
Split general OVB setup tasks from the the stack create

This is the first step in combining the upstream playbook used
for OVB jobs with this one. This should be a no-op change in terms
of what gets run, however the part that is split out is common to
the upstream jobs which create the stack via the testenv broker.

We can then iterate on adding in the testenv broker steps (guarded
by some option) in follow-up patches.

Change-Id: I7cad64e83ed0fbf791b26bdf0e381599d177de7b

commit_message:
Add option for keystone containers to log to stdout/stderr

This adds the option to get the keystone containers to log to stdout.
The option is disabled by default.

If enabled, It also adds a sidecar container that reads the apache
access logs.

bp logging-stdout-rsyslog

Depends-On: I4250ebce75933c8fb3f85b9efdb3e2ade392a60c
Change-Id: Ibb633731a60a16d595d10d38a79ec284da18c5c2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/17/508517/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ContainersLogToStdout: type: boolean default: false log_to_files: {equals: [{get_param: ContainersLogToStdout}, false]} - if: - log_to_files - {} - keystone::logging::use_stderr: true keystone::logging::log_dir: null keystone::logging::log_file: /dev/null # REALLY don't log to a file keystone::wsgi::apache::access_log_file: /dev/stdout keystone::wsgi::apache::error_log_file: /dev/stderr apache::error_log: /dev/stderr map_merge: - if: - log_to_files - # Kolla_bootstrap/db sync runs before permissions set by kolla_config step_2: keystone_init_log: image: &keystone_image {get_param: DockerKeystoneImage} user: root command: ['/bin/bash', '-c', 'chown -R keystone:keystone /var/log/keystone'] volumes: - {} - step_3: keystone_db_sync: image: *keystone_image net: host user: root privileged: false detach: false volumes: &keystone_volumes list_concat: - {get_attr: [ContainersCommon, volumes]} - /var/lib/kolla/config_files/keystone.json:/var/lib/kolla/config_files/config.json:ro - commit_message:
Hande write-root-marker in tag pipeline

The tag-pipeline does not set zuul.branch, so define it to an empty
string if it's unset so that the script passes.

Change-Id: Iddcf722abec5c6a69f40cb109e5563a698ab349c

commit_message:
Set .root-marker variables for openstack-manuals

The ZUUL_* variables are only available for legacy jobs but are
required to write the root-marker file. Set the needed variables.

Change-Id: Ie6e2dbe6f1951f94c918a1aea83ad93e7b39c4b0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/12/515512/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tox_environment: # The tox job writes the root-marker file directly and thus # needs the following variables set: ZUUL_PROJECT: {{ zuul.project.name }} ZUUL_BRANCH: {{ zuul.branch }} ZUUL_UUID: {{ zuul.build }} ZUUL_NEWREF: {{ zuul.ref }}

subject: Fix non-cascade LB delete with children

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-23 17:43:18.000000000', 'files': ['octavia/api/v2/controllers/load_balancer.py', 'octavia/api/v1/controllers/load_balancer.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/c05a8cfb88bd1219a086e8826f7783b64f1e8537', 'message': 'Fix non-cascade LB delete with children

When the user attempts to delete a load balancer, without the cascade option,
the load balancer is locked in "PENDING_DELETE" prior to the check for child
objects. The child object check will return the error to the user, but would
leave the load balancer locked in "PENDING_DELETE".
This patch corrects the order to do the validation prior to locking the
load balancer in "PENDING_DELETE".

Change-Id: If1694743d098b1c1337601770a7b3466a43dda07
Story: 2001256
Task: 5786
'}]
commit_message:
Fix non-cascade LB delete with children

When the user attempts to delete a load balancer, without the cascade option,
the load balancer is locked in "PENDING_DELETE" prior to the check for child
objects. The child object check will return the error to the user, but would
leave the load balancer locked in "PENDING_DELETE".
This patch corrects the order to do the validation prior to locking the
load balancer in "PENDING_DELETE".

Change-Id: If1694743d098b1c1337601770a7b3466a43dda07
Story: 2001256
Task: 5786
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/02/514402/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Do not publish docs when building fails

We just lost the docs.o.o index page: The tox run failed and only a
few files were ready. Since we delete existing content when pushing new,
this removed all our static pages.

Add a safe guard for all doc building: Only collect and publish
documents when we have build them with success. Add this to related
roles like creating/destroying afs as well.

Change-Id: Ife2496fe920bd40d52803705b409e6e621532254

commit_message:
Adding zuul coverage

Change-Id: I451fbc00eaa765f3b32b7e273750c88ca38f4964
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ansible-role-k8s-mariadb refs/changes/55/514255/57 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - hosts: all vars: logs_dir: "/tmp/logs" tasks: - name: Ensure /tmp/logs/ dir file: path: "{{ logs_dir }}" state: "directory" - name: Ensure node directories file: path: "{{ logs_dir }}/{{ item }}" state: "directory" mode: 0777 with_items: - "docker_logs" - "system_logs" - "ansible"

subject: Fixes error handling of DB calls
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-04 15:36:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl/commit/35f5ad9c10d76d73bbba89c4fbcb92301e021741', 'message': 'Fixes error handling of DB calls

There are functions that are wrapped with a `wrap_db_retry` because they
are part of a transaction happening at a higher level inside Neutron. The
problem with wrapping it with that decorator is that without specifying
an `exception_checker` then it only handles `RetryRequests` and not
other types of exceptions that are expected to be received (ie:
`DBDeadLock`). This was an oversight that allowed the related bug to
ocurr and lead to errors reaching Neutron when they could have been
handled at a lower level.

This patch allows the inclusion of an `exception_checker` based on the
Neutron library that handles these DB exceptions + a MySQL issue that
is triggered by `DBDeadLock`s happening (see neutron bug #1590298). It
also keeps the handling of these exceptions at the networking_odl
because we need to do a best effort of allowing to succeed without
having to trigger a rollback of the Neutron action which would be much
costly performance wise.

The affected functions are:
  - `update_db_row_state`
  - `delete_row`
  - `create_pending_row`

Change-Id: I31085cf73618df48f55f3169e071d2cb64c9b018
Closes-Bug: #1714898
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-09-07 13:26:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl/commit/e2dcec1754cb2ab3e8b3ae98405fe11493a827e6', 'message': 'Fixes error handling of DB calls

There are functions that are wrapped with a `wrap_db_retry` because they
are part of a transaction happening at a higher level inside Neutron. The
problem with wrapping it with that decorator is that without specifying
an `exception_checker` then it only handles `RetryRequests` and not
other types of exceptions that are expected to be received (ie:
`DBDeadLock`). This was an oversight that allowed the related bug to
ocurr and lead to errors reaching Neutron when they could have been
handled at a lower level.

This patch allows the inclusion of an `exception_checker` based on the
Neutron library that handles these DB exceptions + a MySQL issue that
is triggered by `DBDeadLock`s happening (see neutron bug #1590298). It
also keeps the handling of these exceptions at the networking_odl
because we need to do a best effort of allowing to succeed without
having to trigger a rollback of the Neutron action which would be much
costly performance wise.

The affected functions are:
  - `update_db_row_state`
  - `delete_row`
  - `create_pending_row`

Change-Id: I31085cf73618df48f55f3169e071d2cb64c9b018
Closes-Bug: #1714898
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-09-07 13:41:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl/commit/eaec1f5aee125466005f2e6944f7ac91a4cb3d88', 'message': 'Fixes error handling of DB calls

There are functions that are wrapped with a `wrap_db_retry` because they
are part of a transaction happening at a higher level inside Neutron. The
problem with wrapping it with that decorator is that without specifying
an `exception_checker` then it only handles `RetryRequests` and not
other types of exceptions that are expected to be received (ie:
`DBDeadLock`). This was an oversight that allowed the related bug to
ocurr and lead to errors reaching Neutron when they could have been
handled at a lower level.

This patch allows the inclusion of an `exception_checker` based on the
Neutron library that handles these DB exceptions + a MySQL issue that
is triggered by `DBDeadLock`s happening (see neutron bug #1590298). It
also keeps the handling of these exceptions at the networking_odl
because we need to do a best effort of allowing to succeed without
having to trigger a rollback of the Neutron action which would be much
costly performance wise.

The affected functions are:
  - `update_db_row_state`
  - `delete_row`
  - `create_pending_row`

Change-Id: I31085cf73618df48f55f3169e071d2cb64c9b018
Closes-Bug: #1714898
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2017-09-17 15:59:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl/commit/a8caaae2296f94e1f4ba1dbe5fd682eb0b373b57', 'message': 'Fixes error handling of DB calls

There are functions that are wrapped with a `wrap_db_retry` because they
are part of a transaction happening at a higher level inside Neutron. The
problem with wrapping it with that decorator is that without specifying
an `exception_checker` then it only handles `RetryRequests` and not
other types of exceptions that are expected to be received (ie:
`DBDeadLock`). This was an oversight that allowed the related bug to
ocurr and lead to errors reaching Neutron when they could have been
handled at a lower level.

This patch allows the inclusion of an `exception_checker` based on the
Neutron library that handles these DB exceptions + a MySQL issue that
is triggered by `DBDeadLock`s happening (see neutron bug #1590298). It
also keeps the handling of these exceptions at the networking_odl
level because we need to do a best effort of allowing to succeed without
having to trigger a rollback of the Neutron action which would be much
costly performance wise.

Moreover, this patch refactors how all the calls to the DB are being
done and tries to retry whenever possible at the highest level, while
adding savepoints or transactions to be able to retry.

Change-Id: I31085cf73618df48f55f3169e071d2cb64c9b018
Closes-Bug: #1714898
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2017-09-17 20:41:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl/commit/c69fe633d2e692ac5a30af0fb385f1c25fc026ed', 'message': 'Fixes error handling of DB calls

There are functions that are wrapped with a `wrap_db_retry` because they
are part of a transaction happening at a higher level inside Neutron. The
problem with wrapping it with that decorator is that without specifying
an `exception_checker` then it only handles `RetryRequests` and not

`DBDeadLock`). This was an oversight that allowed the related bug to
ocurr and lead to errors reaching Neutron when they could have been
handled at a lower level. In addition to this problem, some of the
functions tried to retry without a proper `SAVEPOINT` or transaction
that would allow the retry. Moreover, the retries were often made at a
very low level, when it should have been at a higher level where the
operation is retried as a whole and not "atomic" operations.

having to trigger a rollback of the Neutron action which would be much
costly performance wise. This retry, however is done whenever possible
at the highest level that makes sense, including `SAVEPOINT`s and
transactions depending on the need.

Also, fixes some issues where some of the operations that the driver
does were not able to be retried because of incorrect handling of
exceptions.

Change-Id: I31085cf73618df48f55f3169e071d2cb64c9b018

commit_message:
Fixes error handling of DB calls

There are functions that are wrapped with a `wrap_db_retry` because they
are part of a transaction happening at a higher level inside Neutron. The
problem with wrapping it with that decorator is that without specifying
an `exception_checker` then it only handles `RetryRequests` and not
other types of exceptions that are expected to be received (ie:
`DBDeadLock`). This was an oversight that allowed the related bug to
ocurr and lead to errors reaching Neutron when they could have been
handled at a lower level. In addition to this problem, some of the
functions tried to retry without a proper `SAVEPOINT` or transaction
that would allow the retry. Moreover, the retries were often made at a
very low level, when it should have been at a higher level where the
operation is retried as a whole and not "atomic" operations.

This patch allows the inclusion of an `exception_checker` based on the
Neutron library that handles these DB exceptions + a MySQL issue that
is triggered by `DBDeadLock`s happening (see neutron bug #1590298). It
also keeps the handling of these exceptions at the networking_odl
level because we need to do a best effort of allowing to succeed without
having to trigger a rollback of the Neutron action which would be much
costly performance wise. This retry, however is done whenever possible
at the highest level that makes sense, including `SAVEPOINT`s and
transactions depending on the need.

Also, fixes some issues where some of the operations that the driver
does were not able to be retried because of incorrect handling of
exceptions.

Change-Id: I31085cf73618df48f55f3169e071d2cb64c9b018
Closes-Bug: #1714898
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/84/500584/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import loggingimport six from neutron.db import api as db_api from oslo_db import exception as db_excclass _InnerException(Exception): pass class MockExceptionRaiser(object): def __init__(self, exception): self.exception = exception self.reset_mock() def reset_mock(self): self.call_count = 0 def __getattr__(self, attr): self.call_count += 1 try: raise _InnerException() except _InnerException as e: raise self.exception(e) def _test_db_exceptions_handled(self, method): # NOTE(mpeterson): this test is very verbose, disabling logging logging.disable(logging.CRITICAL) self.addCleanup(logging.disable, logging.NOTSET) # NOTE(mpeterson): make retries faster so it doesn't take a lot. mock.patch.object(db._retry_db_errors, 'retry_interval', new=0.001).start() # NOTE(mpeterson): we want to make sure that it's configured # to MAX_RETRIES before mocking it. self.assertEqual(db._retry_db_errors.max_retries, db_api.MAX_RETRIES) mock.patch.object(db._retry_db_errors, 'max_retries', new=2).start() exceptions = (db_exc.DBDeadlock, exc.StaleDataError, db_exc.DBConnectionError, db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry, db_exc.RetryRequest) r_method = getattr(method, '__wrapped__', method) args = (mock.Mock,) * (six.get_function_code(r_method).co_argcount - 1) for exception in exceptions: mock_session = MockExceptionRaiser(exception) # NOTE(mpeterson): We want to make sure that if we fail, # the exception is still raised. Something that would not happen # when using retry_db_errors. self.assertRaises((exception, _InnerException), method, mock_session, *args) self.assertEqual(2, mock_session.call_count - 1) mock_session.reset_mock() @mock.patch.object(db.models, 'OpenDaylightJournal') def test_create_pending_row_retries_exceptions(self, mock_model): self._test_db_exceptions_handled(db.create_pending_row) def test_delete_row_retries_exceptions(self): self._test_db_exceptions_handled(db.delete_row) def test_update_db_row_state_retries_exceptions(self): self._test_db_exceptions_handled(db.update_db_row_state)

remove pypi link flag for octavia

commit_message:
Lock Ansible to 2.4.0.0 in multi-node-aio

2.4.1.0 appears to have introduced some different behaviors
around vars and breaks.  Locking to 2.4.0.0 until we can
work through those issues.

Change-Id: I0f577e5e3cbeef082f2a870a7214116937e84351

commit_message:
Move the common PTI jobs for releases back to project-config

We like to keep PTI jobs in project-config, move them back to
project-config for openstack/releases.

commit_message:
Fix libvirt exec deps for split-stack

Need to ensure libvirt is installed before the execs that depend on it.

Related bugzilla: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1500527

Change-Id: I7ba62bb3e3a2e43bc57ed33f9b320c698b2c6ad5
Closes-bug: 1723221
(cherry picked from commit fa750232d686ec96b3a07187999958b5bf26ac8e)
(cherry picked from commit e6812a3fa1ea511b82dc5b888ecb2659b0f1dcb0)

commit_message:
Provide a quick workaround for 1727454

Tripleo-common provides an overcloudrc and an overcloudrc.v3 by default.
Problem is that Keystone v2 API was removed in Queens, so we can't rely
on overcloudrc file anymore.

Until we fix that in tripleo-common, let's source the overcloudrc.v3
after Pike, so we can promote to Queens.

This is technical debt that will be cleaned asap.

Change-Id: If2c65959abe2067530e9d8d4546475074e0ef3d9
Related-Bug: #1727454

commit_message:
[upstream] Reordering

In an effort to make things a little less dull in the beginning of
the training, this patch reorders the modules. Students typically
come into the classroom excited to get hands on help with getting
set up and pushing patches. This reordering seeks to maximize that
interest and excitement but also covering all the material by moving
some of the more dry topics down into the workflow related hands on
sections.

This also renames some of the files since the sections are being
combined.

Change-Id: I7debcb027da1bae68e920043d47dc05d7bf6bfc8

deleted_lines: ========================= Registration and Accounts ========================= .. image:: ./_assets/os_background.png :class: fill :width: 100% .. note:: Tags: [new_dev] Accounts ======== - OpenStack Foundation Account - elections (candidacy or vote), presentations - Single sign-on OpenID - code review, bug tracking, blueprints, wiki https://www.openstack.org/join/ =============================== Recommended to join, but not mandatory for code contributions .. image:: ./_assets/12-join-openstack-org.png :width: 100% :class: image-pad-top https://login.ubuntu.com ======================== .. image:: ./_assets/12-01-launchpad-net.png :width: 75% :class: image-pad-top http://review.openstack.org =========================== .. image:: ./_assets/12-02-review.png :width: 100% :class: image-pad-top Sign In ======= .. image:: ./_assets/12-03-signin.png :width: 100% :class: image-pad-top No agreement ============ .. image:: ./_assets/12-04-no-agreement.png :width: 100% :class: image-pad-top New agreement ============= .. image:: ./_assets/12-05-new-agreement.png :width: 100% :class: image-pad-top Sign the Individual agreement ============================= .. image:: ./_assets/12-06-individual-agreement.png :width: 100% :class: image-pad-top Do you work at a company? ========================= - If your contribution is on behalf of a company, have your managers sign the Corporate Contributor License Agreement - When signing up for Foundation Membership, make sure to include the email address you’ll use for code contributions in one of the fields in your profile - https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#account-setup Signed agreement ================ .. image:: ./_assets/12-07-signed-agreement.png :width: 100% :class: image-pad-top Exercise ======== Apply for individual membership (recommended), create a single sign-on account and sign the ICLA

subject: [placement] Enable PUT dict to /allocations/{consumer_uuid}
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-09 16:49:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f86d3919636241a12b22b5709997e9cd7f6fad4b', 'message': '[placement] Enable PUT dict to /allocations/{consumer_uuid}

In microversion 1.11 JSON schema is added to enable PUT to
/allocations/{consumer_uuid} using a dict-based format that is in the
same form as the response at GET /allocations/{consumer_uuid}. This is
considered good practice and also allows the PUT format to be composed
by resource provider uuid, which is useful.

Internally to handlers/allocation.py the same method (_set_allocations)
is used for every microversion. Any previous data structure is
transformed into the dict-ish form. This means that pre-existing tests
(like allocation-bad-class.yaml) continue to exercise the problems it
was made for, but needs to be pinned to an older microversion, rather than
being latest.

One issue revealed by this change that we may wish to address is that
while we require project_id and user_id on PUT they are not present in
the GET response. We can change this (as part of this microversion) if
we want but there are two (probably minor) concerns if we do:

* more complex sql query to join for the project and user info
* if we include that info in the representation, will people
  accidentally send back the _wrong_ project and user info because
  they fail to update it? by not including it, but requiring it, we
  force the caller to set it with the info they have

(Will update the change with the resolution of that issue.)

A subsequence patch will update the placement-api-ref, api history,
and provide a reno for this change.

Change-Id: Ib4b489f29da9571c1669a6eb50e0aa604ff87d6f
Implements: bp symmetric-allocations
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-10-10 11:40:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/25b82717da6db5af519833d0cb93e00157a5cdeb', 'message': '[placement] Enable PUT dict to /allocations/{consumer_uuid}

we want but there are two (probably minor) concerns if we do:

* more complex sql query to join for the project and user info
* if we include that info in the representation, will people
  accidentally send back the _wrong_ project and user info because
  they fail to update it? by not including it, but requiring it, we
  force the caller to set it with the info they have

A subsequence patch will update the placement-api-ref, api history,
and provide a reno for this change.

Change-Id: Ib4b489f29da9571c1669a6eb50e0aa604ff87d6f
Implements: bp symmetric-allocations
Closes-Bug: #1708204
'}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2017-10-16 20:54:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d60c2890a3435dbba379993a87bf779573b1f1de', 'message': '[placement] Enable PUT dict to /allocations/{consumer_uuid}

Internally to handlers/allocation.py the same method (_set_allocations)

commit_message:
[placement] Enable PUT dict to /allocations/{consumer_uuid}

Extend microversion 1.11 to add JSON schema to enable PUT to
/allocations/{consumer_uuid} using a dict-based format that is in the
same form as the response at GET /allocations/{consumer_uuid}. This is
considered good practice and also allows the PUT format to be composed
by resource provider uuid, which is useful.

Internally to handlers/allocation.py the same method (_set_allocations)
is used for every microversion. Any previous data structure is
transformed into the dict-ish form. This means that pre-existing tests
(like allocation-bad-class.yaml) continue to exercise the problems it
was made for, but needs to be pinned to an older microversion, rather than
being latest.

A subsequence patch will update the placement-api-ref, api history,
and provide a reno for this change.

Change-Id: Ib4b489f29da9571c1669a6eb50e0aa604ff87d6f
Implements: bp symmetric-allocations
Closes-Bug: #1708204

commit_message:
[placement] Include project_id and user_id in GET /allocations

In an new microversion, include project_id and user_id in the
output of GET /allocations/{consumer_uuid} so that subsequent
patches which will change the PUT representation (which requires
project_id and user_id) to be structured like the GET response
complete the realignment.

The microversion will be properly documented and reno'd when it
is fully complete, but is introduced in this patch.

Change-Id: Ie69ab746e98e6cf426af1fda34fcb7c127f1b296
